newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: ASEAN says good progress on regional free trade.
newsitem.headline: ASEAN says good progress on regional free trade.

text.p: Southeast Asian nations said on Friday there was good progress towards a free trade area that they expect to boost trade and investment among nearly 500 million people in the region.

Foreign Ministers of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) ended a two-day annual meeting expressing satisfaction at progress mid-way through a 10-year period in which most tariffs are being slashed to between zero and five percent.

"We are at a point where we might be able to achieve the goals of AFTA (the ASEAN Free Trade Area) by the year 2000 instead of the year 2003," ASEAN Secretary-General Ajit Singh told a news conference.
He said that by 2000, more than 87 percent of tariff lines would have zero-to-five percent tariff rates.
"That is no mean achievement for an organisation like AFTA," Singh said, adding that he counted it as one of the major achievements of his five-year tenure in office, which ends on December 31.

A communique at the end of the foreign ministerial meeting noted that the average tariff rates for products included in a common effective preferential tariff (CEPT) scheme had dropped to 6.38 percent from 12.76 percent in 1993.

Singh had told a pre-meeting news conference in Jakarta that intra-ASEAN exports of all products in the January-September period of 1996 had reached $56.1 billion, a 10-percent increase over the same 1995 period.

The communique said the ministers had "emphasised the need to eliminate non-tariff barriers in ASEAN and noted the achievements in this area". These included removal of all customs surcharges at the end of 1996 and prioritisation of 20 product groups for harmonisation of standards.
The ministers reiterated their commitment to "open regionalism and a rule-based multilateral trading system", the communique said.
